awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mapping the Supernova Polarization Landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
Supernovae, or the explosions of massive stars, are critical to understand, both because they produce and disperse many of the atomic elements that make up planets and life, and because their brightness throughout the Universe is used to measure the expansion of the Universe.  Supernova (SN) explosions are not spherical, but rather geometrically complex phenomena, whose aspherical structures cause variations in observed characteristics over time as the explosion evolves. A research collaboration between the University of Denver (DU) and San Diego State University (SDSU) uses an observational technique called spectropolarimetry to provide detailed three-dimensional information about SNe, probing spatial scales that cannot be resolved through direct imaging from earth or even from space. Spectropolarimetry combines detection of the polarization of light from a supernova with measurement of the spectrum of that light.  This information reveals the changing densities, temperatures, and illumination patterns in the ejecta over time; and gives clues to the explosion mechanisms and the nature of progenitor systems.   The project will advance the future of discovery by training students in these types of observations and modeling. It will also contribute to the training of a future diverse STEM community. The investigators will develop a hands-on learning module demonstrating the concept of polarization, for direct integration into two activities: the DU SciTech camp, co-directed by the DU principal investigator (PI), which brings middle-school girls of color to campus for a week-long discovery-based STEM camp each year, and also the extensive outreach activities led by the SDSU PI. 

The scientists will use data collected from 2011 to 2018 by the Supernova Spectropolarimetry (SNSPOL) Project, the largest existing database of spectropolarimetric observations of SNe of all types, which includes 106 SNe of all types, with 50 observed at 3+ epochs.  They will interpret these data with new state-of-the-art modeling techniques. Observational surveys are discovering supernovae and related transients at an ever-increasing rate. The project will broaden the scientific impact of these discoveries by greatly expanding the existing catalog of SNe examined with spectropolarimetry and quantitatively establishing the common signatures of each SN type. The multi-epoch observations in the SNSPOL database trace each SN’s evolution as the photosphere recedes, probing ever deeper into the ejecta and revealing clues to the very nature of the explosion itself. Extracting and analyzing the most salient spectropolarimetric features from these data will make the wealth of information they contain available to future researchers. The results will build a fuller understanding of the 3D nature of SNe of all types and form a key discriminant for stellar explosion models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The most massive stars in the Universe end their lives in energetic supernova explosions that significantly influence their surroundings by injecting energy into the interstellar medium and by creating and distributing new elements that seed future generations of star and planet formation. Understanding the role of supernovae in their galactic ecosystems requires an accurate picture of the mechanisms governing these cosmic explosions. However, because we cannot predict when a supernova will explode, we study these mechanisms indirectly by observing the nature and time-varying behavior of the ejecta, or material blasted into space by the explosion.

For the past decade, my research group at DU has been a partner in the University of Arizona’s Supernova Spectropolarimetry Project (SNSPOL), which amassed the largest observational database of time-dependent SN polarimetric measurements to date. Polarimetry measures the extent to which the light waves we receive from astronomical objects are aligned (“polarized”) by interaction with ionized material. When we observe a supernova with polarimetry, the amount and angle of polarization we measure encodes geometrical information that allows us to quantify the shapes and distributions of elements within the ejecta, and in turn, infer the nature of the progenitor star and characteristics of the explosion.

The SNSPOL Project compiled polarimetric data on over 100 supernovae of all different types. The research funded by this award focused on comparing the behavior of multiple explosions of the same type (defined by their spectral similarities), to explore the extent to which the ejecta shapes revealed by polarimetry are also similar and identify commonly occurring geometrical structures in these explosions. This project was a collaborative effort with a group at San Diego State University, which focused on the Type Ia supernovae; my group investigated the “stripped-envelope” supernovae that arise from progenitor stars with powerful stellar winds.

Some of our key results are as follows:

Ph.D. student Sabrina DeSoto found a highly aspherical geometry in the Type Ib SN 2012au at early times, with helium-rich material concentrated at the poles of the elongated ejecta. At later times, our data revealed a new symmetry axis, indicating the inner ejecta had a different structure than the initial explosion. DeSoto also found that SN 2012au had the highest polarization of any Type Ib supernova previously observed with polarimetry. These findings support previous conjectures that the remnant of SN 2012au is a magnetar with jets directed nearly along our line of sight.

Ph.D. student Christopher Pickens investigated a large sample of Type IIb supernovae and found that most show similar polarization features to each other, but have less dramatic asymmetries than we saw in SN 2012au. Pickens is continuing this work by constructing a general model for Type IIb ejecta that he will compare with inferred models for other subtypes.

Undergraduate physics major Sam Allen analyzed the Type Ib supernova M12045 and found that its global structure was predominantly spherical with some deviations due to a dense helium-rich structure at early times. Its dissimilarity to SN 2012au was striking and suggests the Ib category is heterogeneous.

With collaborators at the University of Arizona, we investigated the polarimetric behavior of a large sample of Type IIn supernovae, which are surrounded by circumstellar gas and dust when they explode. One of these, SN 2014ab, showed very low polarization, indicating that its ejecta were oriented with the elongation axis along our line of sight. Another, SN 2017hcc, had unusually high polarization, suggesting an alignment between the pre-supernova circumstellar material created by the progenitor winds and the orientation of the ejecta themselves. As a group, the Type IIn explosions reveal the presence of dusty circumstellar material with axisymmetric configurations. Both results suggest that the progenitors are likely binary stars.

Our group also used this award to fund DU SciTech, a weeklong summer day camp aimed at providing scientific experiences to middle-school students, particularly girls of color. The campers came primarily from low-income families; they participated at no cost and took home all camp materials including telescopes, tripods, computers and peripherals, and insect-collecting kits. 2019 campers contributed to a study showing that invasive cheatgrass preferentially grows under streetlights, implying that light pollution is linked to ecosystem change. 2023 campers found that artificial light discourages insect reproduction. We also used pre- and post-camp surveys to establish that camp participation strengthened the campers’ belief in their ability to do science.
